abstract.para: Simple manual for the TERESAH web app.

chapter.title: Introduction to TERESAH
chapter.para: Welcome to TERESAH. TERESAH (standing for Tools E-Registry for E-Social science, Arts and Humanities) is a web based application for the collection and organisation of data research tools. It was created using funds from the Seventh Framework Programme.

section.title: Creating an account for TERESAH
section.para: Before starting to use TERESAH, you need an account. It is also possible to log in using so-called federated login providers such as linked-in, but for now, lets create a dedicated account.

On the front page, click on "sign in" in the upper right corner.
The top bar (no user currently logged in)
Next you will be taken to the login page. Since we are assuming that you don't have an account yet, click on "Sign up" below the "Password" field.

para.emphasis: The sign in form. The link to sign up for a new account is highlighted.

section.para: Now we need some basic information about you: (1) Your name, (2) Your prefered locale (currently English and Swedish are available), (3) A mail adress (4) The password you want to use. Repeat the password. Once you have filled out the fields correctly, click on "Sign Up".

para.emphasis: The sign up form for creating a new user account
The mail sent to new users.

section.para: Once your application has been processed, you will get a confirmation mail to the address you used in the previous step.

section.title: Exporting tool RDF info
section.para: When viewing a tool in TERESAH, you can export information about it in RDF format. Depending of what you want to use the RDF for, you can export it in different languages.

listitem.para: RDF/JSONLD - A JSON dialect for exchange of links

section.para: Just click on the format you want, and your browser should either show it in a separate page or let you download and save it in a file.

section.title: Adding a new tool
section.para: So far we have only looked at tools put into TERESAH by other people, or taken from external data sources. Now we will create one ourselves.
Important note: in order to actually add a tool, you need to have a user type of Collaborator, Supervisor or Administrator. See the reference section on user types for more info

section.title: Removing an existing tool
section.para: Removing an existing tool is, quite understandably, even easier than adding a new one.

chapter.title: The TERESAH API
chapter.para: Since the TERESAH API is still under implementation, this manual is not currently covering it. For up-to-date information regarding the API, se the folder TERESAH/documentation/api/v1/ in the git repository.

section.title: Special terms and assorted acronyms
section.para: TERESAH uses some specific terminology and technical words that you may or may not be familiar with. Here we will attempt to clarify things.

para.emphasis: Tools E-Registry for E-Social science, Arts and Humanities

listitem.para: Application Programming Interface - a defined way for programs to "speak" to each other.
A facette is a category that is used to sort different tools. Facets include (for example) the developer of the tool, or the platform it runs on.
In TERESAH, a tool refers to a specific piece of software (and its page in TERESAH) that might be useful to researchers.

section.title: Types of users
section.para: Different users have different rights in TERESAH. These are the types of user, and what rights they have.

listitem.para: User with registered account. Can edit own profile and create lists of tools. The "basic" type of user - all the other types of user "builds" on this type.
Authenticated user with collaborator status. Can add and edit tools and data types
Authenticated user with supervisor status. Can add, edit and remove tools, data types, data sources, list activities, and harvest other data sources.
Authenticated user with administrator status. Has full access to all administrative functions.
